content.raw: After some thought, I'm pretty sure I put it in the private section on purpose because there is no need for users to see the class's destructor or to know that it's virtual. The goal was to compartmentalize the API so that functions which users should be aware of will be at the top, and then implementation details will be tucked away at the bottom.
content.html: After some thought, I'm pretty sure I put it in the private section on purpose because there is no need for users to see the class's destructor or to know that it's virtual. The goal was to compartmentalize the API so that functions which users should be aware of will be at the top, and then implementation details will be tucked away at the bottom.

content.raw: There was a discussion about this with @sloretz and we decided that it would make the most sense for the `PLUGIN_API_VERSION` of the first release to be 1 (because it would be kind of weird if the API version of our first release were... 3 or 4+). Since we're still in the pre-release + development/testing stage and our only users are internal, we're keeping it at 1 and not worrying about backwards compatibility until the first official release.
content.html: There was a discussion about this with @sloretz and we decided that it would make the most sense for the PLUGIN_API_VERSION of the first release to be 1 (because it would be kind of weird if the API version of our first release were... 3 or 4+). Since we're still in the pre-release + development/testing stage and our only users are internal, we're keeping it at 1 and not worrying about backwards compatibility until the first official release.

~~~
/Users/jenkins/workspace/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/ign-common/src/StringUtils.cc:70:14: error: call to 'abs' is ambiguous
      return std::abs(_N) == 1? _singular : _plural;
             ^~~~~~~~
/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Toolchains/XcodeDefault.xctoolchain/usr/bin/../include/c++/v1/cmath:664:1: note: candidate function
abs(float __lcpp_x) _NOEXCEPT {return fabsf(__lcpp_x);}
^
/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Toolchains/XcodeDefault.xctoolchain/usr/bin/../include/c++/v1/cmath:668:1: note: candidate function
abs(double __lcpp_x) _NOEXCEPT {return fabs(__lcpp_x);}
^

abs(long double __lcpp_x) _NOEXCEPT {return fabsl(__lcpp_x);}
^
1 error generated.
~~~

I think maybe we want `<cstdlib>` instead of `<cmath>`?

* http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/numeric/math/abs

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
That function is definitely defined in `src/Plugin.cc`, so this strikes me as a linker error. I'd say that maybe we're neglecting to link the `ignition-common0` library to the `INTEGRATION_plugin` test, but that test is built using `ign_build_tests(~)`, and it very clearly calls `target_link_libraries(${BINARY_NAME} ... ${PROJECT_NAME_LOWER})`, where `${PROJECT_NAME_LOWER}` is equivalent to the main library's target name.

I genuinely don't know what could cause this, short of a peculiar bug in our cmake script that only shows up on Mac.

That function is definitely defined in src/Plugin.cc, so this strikes me as a linker error. I'd say that maybe we're neglecting to link the ignition-common0 library to the INTEGRATION_plugin test, but that test is built using ign_build_tests(~), and it very clearly calls target_link_libraries(${BINARY_NAME} ... ${PROJECT_NAME_LOWER}), where ${PROJECT_NAME_LOWER} is equivalent to the main library's target name.

I genuinely don't know what could cause this, short of a peculiar bug in our cmake script that only shows up on Mac.

content.raw: nitpick: remove the Get prefix
content.html: nitpick: remove the Get prefix

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
I know there's been a trend to remove the `Get` keyword from function names, but I feel it belongs here for a few reasons:

1. I believe function names should (with some exceptions) express actions, and I think many developers and users share that expectation. The word "Interface" in particular can be either a noun or a verb, and when it's used as a function name I think there's an expectation that it will take on the verb (action) meaning. That would imply that calling `plugin->Interface<PhysicsEngine>()` is instructing the plugin to interface itself with the physics engine (whatever that might mean) when what it's really doing is giving you access to the physics engine interface that the plugin provides. Therefore, I think removing the `Get` keyword would be particularly confusing in this case.

2. If the goal of removing the `Get` keyword is consistency throughout the code base, then I would point to our `sdformat` API which contains `[Get|Has][Element|Attribute]` which I think strongly parallels the `[Get|Has]Interface` of this Plugin API.
content.html:
I know there's been a trend to remove the Get keyword from function names, but I feel it belongs here for a few reasons:

  1. I believe function names should (with some exceptions) express actions, and I think many developers and users share that expectation. The word "Interface" in particular can be either a noun or a verb, and when it's used as a function name I think there's an expectation that it will take on the verb (action) meaning. That would imply that calling plugin->Interface<PhysicsEngine>() is instructing the plugin to interface itself with the physics engine (whatever that might mean) when what it's really doing is giving you access to the physics engine interface that the plugin provides. Therefore, I think removing the Get keyword would be particularly confusing in this case.

  2. If the goal of removing the Get keyword is consistency throughout the code base, then I would point to our sdformat API which contains [Get|Has][Element|Attribute] which I think strongly parallels the [Get|Has]Interface of this Plugin API.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
Just some historical context, we started removing the `Get` prefix on Gazebo as we updated the API to use Ignition libraries and the PIMPL idiom. `sdformat` still has it because it is an older API. I believe the plan is to eventually change all APIs to be consistent. In general, if you see some `Get` function on Gazebo / Ignition / SDF, this means it is old...

I see your point regarding having a verb, but it is not uncommon for APIs to not have a a `get` on getters. But I agree that the fact that `Interface` is both a verb and a noun could be a source of confusion. But at this point, I think the path of least friction is to stick with the latest style and make the API consistent.
content.html:
Just some historical context, we started removing the Get prefix on Gazebo as we updated the API to use Ignition libraries and the PIMPL idiom. sdformat still has it because it is an older API. I believe the plan is to eventually change all APIs to be consistent. In general, if you see some Get function on Gazebo / Ignition / SDF, this means it is old...

I see your point regarding having a verb, but it is not uncommon for APIs to not have a a get on getters. But I agree that the fact that Interface is both a verb and a noun could be a source of confusion. But at this point, I think the path of least friction is to stick with the latest style and make the API consistent.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
In almost every example of a major library API having a getter without `Get` that I can think of, it's because the function is returning a mutable reference to a member variable (which deteriorates to a const-reference when the object is const-qualified). In such a case, it makes sense for the function to have a noun name because the function is effectively an alias for the member variable itself, and you can operate on the function as if it is an object (noun). An example of this would be a `Vector2d` class which provides `x()` and `y()` which are aliases for the x and y components of the `std::array<double, 2>` member variable.

I think it is much much less common for a function to provide one-directional access to something (an immutable reference) without being qualified by the `Get` keyword. In this case, if a user calls `GetInterface<PhysicsEngine>()` they cannot use that function to change the underlying physics engine pointer that is being used by the plugin, which means the function is effectively providing an immutable reference to its physics engine interface pointer.
content.html:
In almost every example of a major library API having a getter without Get that I can think of, it's because the function is returning a mutable reference to a member variable (which deteriorates to a const-reference when the object is const-qualified). In such a case, it makes sense for the function to have a noun name because the function is effectively an alias for the member variable itself, and you can operate on the function as if it is an object (noun). An example of this would be a Vector2d class which provides x() and y() which are aliases for the x and y components of the std::array<double, 2> member variable.

I think it is much much less common for a function to provide one-directional access to something (an immutable reference) without being qualified by the Get keyword. In this case, if a user calls GetInterface<PhysicsEngine>() they cannot use that function to change the underlying physics engine pointer that is being used by the plugin, which means the function is effectively providing an immutable reference to its physics engine interface pointer.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
I did some more looking around, and I have to admit that I'm seeing several large popular libraries that are not using the `get` keyword in their immutable getter functions (Qt and Boost being two examples).

I still think it would make much more semantic sense to always use `Get` for immutable getter functions and then only leave it out for mutable getter functions (which are really aliases for member variables), but I have to acknowledge that this is not a universally practiced style among well-established C++ libraries.
content.html:
I did some more looking around, and I have to admit that I'm seeing several large popular libraries that are not using the get keyword in their immutable getter functions (Qt and Boost being two examples).

I still think it would make much more semantic sense to always use Get for immutable getter functions and then only leave it out for mutable getter functions (which are really aliases for member variables), but I have to acknowledge that this is not a universally practiced style among well-established C++ libraries.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
Thanks for digging deep into this. As far as I understand it, there is no universally acceptable practice regarding the use of get and each library just adopts their own style.

I don't have a strong opinion about it except for the fact that we've been putting a lot of effort on getting rid of `Get`. I hear your worries about semantics, but I suspect that it is a big stretch to think that users will interpret `Get` as meaning "return an immutable reference as opposed to a mutable one" .

In any case, I'm ok with leaving this the way it is if no one else has a problem with it.
content.html:
Thanks for digging deep into this. As far as I understand it, there is no universally acceptable practice regarding the use of get and each library just adopts their own style.

I don't have a strong opinion about it except for the fact that we've been putting a lot of effort on getting rid of Get. I hear your worries about semantics, but I suspect that it is a big stretch to think that users will interpret Get as meaning "return an immutable reference as opposed to a mutable one" .

In any case, I'm ok with leaving this the way it is if no one else has a problem with it.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
I guess from my personal view, I genuinely don't understand the motive behind not using `Get` (at best, you save yourself from typing three letters) while I see numerous disadvantages to it, including (but not limited to)

1. Awkward semantics: Function names end up being nouns, even though they're performing a task by retrieving a resource.

2. Naming imbalance: Here we have `GetInterface` and `HasInterface`, but we would end up with `Interface` and `HasInterface` if we removed `Get`.

3. Lower quality of life for autocomplete users: Many people who use autocomplete like to be able to type `g-e-t-` to preview what kind of parameters they are able to retrieve from an object. Removing `Get` would take that away from them (... and from me). This also applies to anyone who might want to `ctrl-F` or `/get` search the API for getter functions.
content.html:
I guess from my personal view, I genuinely don't understand the motive behind not using Get (at best, you save yourself from typing three letters) while I see numerous disadvantages to it, including (but not limited to)

  1. Awkward semantics: Function names end up being nouns, even though they're performing a task by retrieving a resource.

  2. Naming imbalance: Here we have GetInterface and HasInterface, but we would end up with Interface and HasInterface if we removed Get.

  3. Lower quality of life for autocomplete users: Many people who use autocomplete like to be able to type g-e-t- to preview what kind of parameters they are able to retrieve from an object. Removing Get would take that away from them (... and from me). This also applies to anyone who might want to ctrl-F or /get search the API for getter functions.

content.raw: I'm ok with `Get`

content.raw: I'd prefer no significant changes our style. The amount of work to convert our existing code would be tremendous with little benefit. No style is perfect.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
Another thing to consider in this specific case is conflict between the template parameter and function name. We can't use `Interface` as the name of the template parameter if it is also the function name. So we'd end up with an API that looks like

    public: template <typename T>
    T* Interface();

which I think is much less clear and expressive than the current proposal

    public: template <typename Interface>
    Interface* GetInterface();

When the name of the template parameter is something unexpressive like `T`, I think it becomes much less clear what kinds of types the function is intended to be used for. We could mangle the template parameter name into something like `IFace`, but in some ways I think that might be even worse than `T`.

If we're not willing to make an exception to the style for this function, then I'll remove the `Get`, but I believe it will be more harmful than beneficial in the long run.
content.html:
Another thing to consider in this specific case is conflict between the template parameter and function name. We can't use Interface as the name of the template parameter if it is also the function name. So we'd end up with an API that looks like

public: template <typename T>
T* Interface();

which I think is much less clear and expressive than the current proposal

public: template <typename Interface>
Interface* GetInterface();

When the name of the template parameter is something unexpressive like T, I think it becomes much less clear what kinds of types the function is intended to be used for. We could mangle the template parameter name into something like IFace, but in some ways I think that might be even worse than T.

If we're not willing to make an exception to the style for this function, then I'll remove the Get, but I believe it will be more harmful than beneficial in the long run.

content.html: Here is my proposal.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
This compiles with GCC (which tends to be more flexible with the rules), but it does not compile with Clang (which tends to be much more strict about adherence to the standard).

But even beyond issues with compilation, I think it's dangerous to be shadowing type names with function names, even if we could find a way to compile it.

For example, in the `gazebo::Model` class we have a `GetLink` member function. If we were to continue our current trend and remove the `Get` keyword from that function, then its name would end up as `Link`. We could *technically* get the code to compile like that, because the compiler would usually have enough context to distinguish between the type name versus the member function name, but I still consider this problematic, for the following reasons:

 - I find that human developers and maintainers have difficulty recognizing the difference between the function names and type names when they are identical, even though the compiler can easily distinguish between them based on context.

- The purpose behind giving expressive names to functions and types is to avoid this kind of ambiguity and make the code easier to read. If a function and a type are ending up with the same name, then I don't think that name is expressive enough. A type name should usually express an object and therefore be a noun, while a function name should usually express an action and therefore be a verb or a [predicate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predicate_(grammar)). There will certainly be exceptions to that rule of thumb, but our code style is actively pushing functions to have noun-like names, which I think distorts the concept of a function.

- On a more technical level, sharing a name makes it more difficult for most static analyzers or code model generators to quickly produce a correct model of the code. Anecdotally, Qt Creator (which is my IDE of choice) is mistaking the `Interface` template parameter as being the same symbol as the `Interface` function name. The Clang code model generator just outright rejects the code, which is unsurprising since Clang refuses to compile it. Other static analyzers (like what we use for code coverage) are likely to have similar issues with mistaking the symbols, since they often sacrifice accuracy for speed.

- This also makes basic upkeep like refactoring much much more difficult (e.g. I bet you found it pretty easy to convert `GetInterface` into `Interface` without affecting anything else, but now you would not find it very easy to convert the function name `Interface` into another name without also changing the names of all the template parameters).

One possible solution in this specific case would be to change the name from `GetInterface` to `QueryInterface`. Admittedly, the name `QueryInterface` is probably a more expressive and more accurate name anyway, since the function does not make any guarantee that it will return the requested interface (if the requested interface is unavailable, it returns a `nullptr`). The word `Query` probably does a better job of expressing that behavior than `Get`. For illustrative purposes, I've made this change in a branch here 82ee8290591f.

But in a more broad sense, a code style rule which reduces the expressiveness of function names strikes me as harmful, so I would urge us to reconsider its enforcement. I wouldn't necessarily propose reverting any function names to bring back a `Get` which has been removed, but I would hope that we can avoid actively reducing the expressiveness of existing function names.
content.html:
This compiles with GCC (which tends to be more flexible with the rules), but it does not compile with Clang (which tends to be much more strict about adherence to the standard).

But even beyond issues with compilation, I think it's dangerous to be shadowing type names with function names, even if we could find a way to compile it.

For example, in the gazebo::Model class we have a GetLink member function. If we were to continue our current trend and remove the Get keyword from that function, then its name would end up as Link. We could technically get the code to compile like that, because the compiler would usually have enough context to distinguish between the type name versus the member function name, but I still consider this problematic, for the following reasons:

  • I find that human developers and maintainers have difficulty recognizing the difference between the function names and type names when they are identical, even though the compiler can easily distinguish between them based on context.

  • The purpose behind giving expressive names to functions and types is to avoid this kind of ambiguity and make the code easier to read. If a function and a type are ending up with the same name, then I don't think that name is expressive enough. A type name should usually express an object and therefore be a noun, while a function name should usually express an action and therefore be a verb or a predicate. There will certainly be exceptions to that rule of thumb, but our code style is actively pushing functions to have noun-like names, which I think distorts the concept of a function.

  • On a more technical level, sharing a name makes it more difficult for most static analyzers or code model generators to quickly produce a correct model of the code. Anecdotally, Qt Creator (which is my IDE of choice) is mistaking the Interface template parameter as being the same symbol as the Interface function name. The Clang code model generator just outright rejects the code, which is unsurprising since Clang refuses to compile it. Other static analyzers (like what we use for code coverage) are likely to have similar issues with mistaking the symbols, since they often sacrifice accuracy for speed.

  • This also makes basic upkeep like refactoring much much more difficult (e.g. I bet you found it pretty easy to convert GetInterface into Interface without affecting anything else, but now you would not find it very easy to convert the function name Interface into another name without also changing the names of all the template parameters).

One possible solution in this specific case would be to change the name from GetInterface to QueryInterface. Admittedly, the name QueryInterface is probably a more expressive and more accurate name anyway, since the function does not make any guarantee that it will return the requested interface (if the requested interface is unavailable, it returns a nullptr). The word Query probably does a better job of expressing that behavior than Get. For illustrative purposes, I've made this change in a branch here 82ee8290591f.

But in a more broad sense, a code style rule which reduces the expressiveness of function names strikes me as harmful, so I would urge us to reconsider its enforcement. I wouldn't necessarily propose reverting any function names to bring back a Get which has been removed, but I would hope that we can avoid actively reducing the expressiveness of existing function names.

content.raw: there is a subtle difference with `[=]` on line 108 and `[&]` on line 123
content.html: there is a subtle difference with [=] on line 108 and [&] on line 123

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
That difference doesn't actually impact anything in this particular code.

The `=` versus `&` determines how variables from the lambda's parent scope that are used within the lambda will be "captured" by the lambda (by copy or by reference). The lambdas here aren't using any variables from their parent scope, so the "capture method" ends up being irrelevant.

I definitely think Shane is right that we can reduce the duplication, and I'm always in favor of DRYness.
content.html:
That difference doesn't actually impact anything in this particular code.

The = versus & determines how variables from the lambda's parent scope that are used within the lambda will be "captured" by the lambda (by copy or by reference). The lambdas here aren't using any variables from their parent scope, so the "capture method" ends up being irrelevant.

I definitely think Shane is right that we can reduce the duplication, and I'm always in favor of DRYness.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw: Is `HELPER_2` needed? It seems to be a Stringify macro call in all cases.
content.html: Is HELPER_2 needed? It seems to be a Stringify macro call in all cases.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
Sadly it *is* needed (at least, based on all the macro-writing strategy guides I could find). The problem boils down to the syntax required by the preprocessor to apply the stringification correctly to the substituted tokens.

Basically, if we tried to take the `_HELPER_2` functions out of the implementation, we'd end up producing something like

`_Pragma("clang diagnostic ignored IGN_COMMON_DELETE_NON_VIRTUAL_DESTRUCTOR")`

instead of what we really want

`_Pragma("clang diagnostic ignored -Wdelete-non-virtual-dtor")`
content.html:
Sadly it is needed (at least, based on all the macro-writing strategy guides I could find). The problem boils down to the syntax required by the preprocessor to apply the stringification correctly to the substituted tokens.

Basically, if we tried to take the _HELPER_2 functions out of the implementation, we'd end up producing something like

_Pragma("clang diagnostic ignored IGN_COMMON_DELETE_NON_VIRTUAL_DESTRUCTOR")

instead of what we really want

_Pragma("clang diagnostic ignored -Wdelete-non-virtual-dtor")

content.html:
sorry, we can revert it if it's irrelevant; I was just trying to clean up the CI. some claim it is an error in clang to complain about this:

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
It seems that it might be an intentional warning emitted by clang to try to reduce some kind of ambiguities that may arise from initializer-list construction. To be perfectly honest, initializer-lists are one of the few things from C++ whose syntax and usage patterns I find perplexing.

I think the clang warning is probably a fair one. This change doesn't seem harmful, so we may as well keep it.
content.html:
It seems that it might be an intentional warning emitted by clang to try to reduce some kind of ambiguities that may arise from initializer-list construction. To be perfectly honest, initializer-lists are one of the few things from C++ whose syntax and usage patterns I find perplexing.

I think the clang warning is probably a fair one. This change doesn't seem harmful, so we may as well keep it.

content.raw:
In the [next PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/59) there is an enormous amount of coverage in the integration test. I left it out of this PR because it would have been messy for the version history if we pulled over that integration test and then cut away the tests of the specialized plugins.

The `Plugin` class tests are all in the integration test because the `Plugin` class can't really do anything without the `PluginLoader`, which I think requires the tests to fall under INTEGRATION rather than UNIT.

content.raw: There is significant momentum behind the lack of `Get`. For example, ign-math, ign-transport, ign-rendering, ign-sensors, ign-msgs, ign-gui, and gazebo would all have to be changed. That is not something we should undertake. Consistency across libraries is something we should maintain.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
In the original pull request, there was an explanation of why I named it like this, but it seems to have gotten lost in the decomposition. The gist of it is:

The role of this function is to covert from our custom `PluginPtr` class (which was left out of this pull request, but is being introduced in pull request 59) to an STL-based `std::shared_ptr` class, so the change in code style is meant to reflect that transition. After all, we're giving them a `shared_ptr`, not a `SharedPtr`.
content.html:
In the original pull request, there was an explanation of why I named it like this, but it seems to have gotten lost in the decomposition. The gist of it is:

The role of this function is to covert from our custom PluginPtr class (which was left out of this pull request, but is being introduced in pull request 59) to an STL-based std::shared_ptr class, so the change in code style is meant to reflect that transition. After all, we're giving them a shared_ptr, not a SharedPtr.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
Thanks for the explanation. It sounds reasonable, however there is a benefit to sticking to our style standards for code that we create and distribute. One benefit is consistency across libraries.  Another benefit is that a switch in style is a signal to a user that they are now leaving ignition/gazebo/etc and entering a different library. I'd also prefer not to create a list of exceptions to the already long list of rules. 

The return type of the function should be enough information to a user that they will get a `std::shared_ptr`.
content.html:
Thanks for the explanation. It sounds reasonable, however there is a benefit to sticking to our style standards for code that we create and distribute. One benefit is consistency across libraries. Another benefit is that a switch in style is a signal to a user that they are now leaving ignition/gazebo/etc and entering a different library. I'd also prefer not to create a list of exceptions to the already long list of rules.

The return type of the function should be enough information to a user that they will get a std::shared_ptr.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw: Can you remove the `Private` prefix to these functions? It seems redundant.
content.html: Can you remove the Private prefix to these functions? It seems redundant.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
I had two motivations for having `Private` in the name:

1. Avoid name collisions (or more accurately, name confusion) between this function and the public-facing `GetInterface<T>(~)` function
2. Emphasize that this is not a function that should be considered for use by an end-user.

Technically there would not be a name collision between this function and `GetInterface<T>(~)` even if we removed the `Private` because one function is templated and the other isn't. However, I'd like to avoid issue tickets where users are asking why they can't retrieve an interface using `plugin->GetInterface(myInterfaceName)` when the only problem is that they forgot to specify the template parameter.
content.html:
I had two motivations for having Private in the name:

  1. Avoid name collisions (or more accurately, name confusion) between this function and the public-facing GetInterface<T>(~) function
  2. Emphasize that this is not a function that should be considered for use by an end-user.

Technically there would not be a name collision between this function and GetInterface<T>(~) even if we removed the Private because one function is templated and the other isn't. However, I'd like to avoid issue tickets where users are asking why they can't retrieve an interface using plugin->GetInterface(myInterfaceName) when the only problem is that they forgot to specify the template parameter.

content.raw: What about negative values of _N (also N shouldn't be capitalized)? Is -1 singular or plural?
content.html: What about negative values of _N (also N shouldn't be capitalized)? Is -1 singular or plural?

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
Whether `-1` is singular or plural is a loaded question, which I think depends a lot on context. You can find a whole discussion on it [here](https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/9735/is-1-followed-by-a-singular-or-plural-noun).

I think the view I favor the most is [this one](https://english.stackexchange.com/a/9743), but it's not terribly helpful since the conclusion is that sometimes it will be singular and sometimes it will be plural, depending on how the quantity is being read.

I have no problem restricting the singular case to *only* be when `_n==1` if that's what people would prefer.
content.html:
Whether -1 is singular or plural is a loaded question, which I think depends a lot on context. You can find a whole discussion on it here.

I think the view I favor the most is this one, but it's not terribly helpful since the conclusion is that sometimes it will be singular and sometimes it will be plural, depending on how the quantity is being read.

I have no problem restricting the singular case to only be when _n==1 if that's what people would prefer.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
I changed `_N` to `_n` in db3f6c4

I'm not clear on where we should stand regarding the plurality of `-1`.
content.html:
I changed _N to _n in db3f6c4

I'm not clear on where we should stand regarding the plurality of -1.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw: This once again shows how English such and easy language. I also like your conclusion, and agree that it would be difficult to implement. How about we use the singular for all cases of -1? It feels that the singular will cause fewer problems.
content.html: This once again shows how English such and easy language. I also like your conclusion, and agree that it would be difficult to implement. How about we use the singular for all cases of -1? It feels that the singular will cause fewer problems.
